options.content:
✅ Check that there is at least one instance of MongoDB running in your workload.

✅ Check that the minimum uptime to detect restarts of the instances. The number displayed is the running time of the instance restarted more recently.

✅ Check the asserts inside of your instance to detect errors.

✅ Check that the response time is below your expected latency. 

⛳ MongoDB relies on an in-memory cache to minimize the disk operations. Low performance of cache can impact directly the response time. 

✅ Check the asserts inside of your instance to detect errors.

⛳ The page memory faults panel shows the total number of page faults that require disk operations. 
* Page faults refer to operations that require the database server to access data that isn’t available in active memory. 
* This value may increase dramatically during moments of poor performance and may correlate with limited memory environments and larger data sets. 
  * 👉 Check the memory usage and ensure that the instance has enough memory
*  Limited and sporadic page faults do not necessarily indicate an issue

MongoDB uses locks to manage the shared access to resources. 

✅ Check the global lock values:
* Low values indicate that operations have held the global lock frequently for shorter periods of time. 
* High values indicate that operations have held global lock infrequently for longer periods of time

⛳ The lock queue is the number of operations that have wait for locks. A consistent high value can be a symptom of concurrency issues:
* ✅ Check that the lock queue has not a sustained high value
